article.headline: Stanford 80, Oregon State 66
article.story: STANFORD, Calif. (AP) -- Chris Hernandez came off a screen and threw up a successful 3-pointer. Seconds later he did it again and Stanford was on its way to its first conference victory. Hernandez scored 10 of his 20 points in the final five minutes in helping Stanford beat Oregon State 80-66 on Thursday night. "Every time I shoot, I tell myself they're all good," Hernandez said. "When I got a good look I had to put it up." Hernandez reached double figures in consecutive games for just the second time this season, making five of eight shots from the field, including 4-of-6 from long range, and all six of his foul shots. "Chris will be Chris," Stanford coach Trent Johnson said. "When it was close we pulled away and executed." Lawrence Hill added 13 points, including a clutch 3-pointer in the final minutes as the Cardinal (5-6, 1-2 Pac-10) beat Oregon State for the 13th straight time at home. Dan Grunfeld scored 14 (making all 10 of his foul shots) and Peter Prowitt added a career-high 12. Chris Stephens scored 16 points to lead the Beavers (7-6, 0-2), who lost their 14th consecutive conference road game. Jason Fontenet had 14 points and Marcel Jones added 11. Stephens made his only free throw to extend his streak to 25 straight. The school record is 30. Oregon State missed its chance to beat the Cardinal two straight for the first time since 1993. "Neither team was stopping each other and then Chris Hernandez had a stretch there that changed everything," Oregon State coach Jay John said. "The big shot he hits, the 3-pointers, and then he gets bumped and the parade continues. Having that happen where they get a lot of points at the line was one of my biggest fears." The Cardinal were 31 of 35 from the foul line, and made their final eight attempts. Stanford played without its top player and one of its top reserves. Senior Matt Haryasz, a 6-foot-10 forward and Stanford's leading scorer and rebounder, missed the game with a sprained left ankle he sustained in Saturday's loss at USC. Fred Washington missed his fifth straight with tendinitis in his left knee. "We're used to playing with Matt," Stanford's Taj Finger said. "With him out, we have to step up and make big plays because his offense is not going to be there." Hill had problems breathing and left Monday's practice early. Tests performed on Tuesday came back negative. Beavers guard Lamar Hurd exorcised some personal demons against Stanford. The four-year starter at point guard had not made a field goal against the Cardinal since his freshman season and had missed 16 in a row against them until making two of his first three shots on Thursday night. His 2.0 scoring average in six previous games against Stanford was his worst against any Pac-10 team. Hurd, who started 89 of his first 91 games, came off the bench in six straight before starting against the Cardinal. He's been alternating between both guard spots but assumed a primary role at the point as he has the best assist-to-turnover ratio on the team. He matched his previous season high of four assists in the first half alone. He finished with seven. The teams exchanged the lead several times through most of the second half, and the lead didn't get larger than three points either way until Hernandez hit a 3-pointer to put Stanford up 58-54 with just under five minutes to play. Hernandez hit another 3-pointer 37 seconds later and Stanford took control with a 19-3 run. "They went right through us for a while," Hurd said. "They made some big shots and all of a sudden we have to come back and answer and we couldn't." Oregon State fell behind early but an 18-6 run helped give the Beavers a 31-30 halftime lead.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
